Claim: Inhalation of steam from hot water kills COVID-19
Explaination: Inhalation of steam from hot water does not kill coronavirus. There is no research conducted to support the same.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Inhalation of steam from hot water kills COVID-19

Explanation:Inhalation of steam from hot water does not kill coronavirus. There is no research conducted to support the same.

https://english.factcrescendo.com/2020/03/30/fact-check-inhalation-of-hot-steam-kills-coronavirus/?check=1

Claim: A Facebook post in Australia claims sufferers of respiratory conditions can access a “rescue pack” of medication by asking a general practitioner.
Explaination: AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be misleading. “Rescue packs” containing steroids and antibiotics are a UK scheme available only to certain people. The federal Department of Health confirmed that people in Australia with pre-existing COPD conditions can only access a “rescue pack” of medication if it has been previously prescribed.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A Facebook post in Australia claims sufferers of respiratory conditions can access a “rescue pack” of medication by asking a general practitioner.

Explanation:AAP FactCheck found the Facebook post to be misleading. “Rescue packs” containing steroids and antibiotics are a UK scheme available only to certain people. The federal Department of Health confirmed that people in Australia with pre-existing COPD conditions can only access a “rescue pack” of medication if it has been previously prescribed.

https://www.aap.com.au/lung-disease-rescue-packs-claim-blows-into-australia-from-the-uk/

Claim: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.
Explaination: The video is not related to coronavirus but with London riots that happened in 2011. The 2011 England riots, more widely known as the London Riots, were a series of riots between 6 and 11 August 2011, when thousands of people rioted in cities and towns across England, saw looting, arson, and mass deployment of police, and resulted in the deaths of five people.
Label: FALSE

annotations.label: Prot
annotations.remark: This combines several claims and each can be attributed to a different category

html:
Claim: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.

Explanation:The video is not related to coronavirus but with London riots that happened in 2011. The 2011 England riots, more widely known as the London Riots, were a series of riots between 6 and 11 August 2011, when thousands of people rioted in cities and towns across England, saw looting, arson, and mass deployment of police, and resulted in the deaths of five people.

https://www.newschecker.in/article/news-detail/275_15320709

Claim: Rainbow shimmers behind a COVID-19 disinfectant truck in China.

Label: False

Explanation:It's from March 2019.

https://factcheck.afp.com/video-has-circulated-online-least-march-2019-months-novel-coronavirus-outbreak

Claim: Images of the medical facility shared with the claim that the Indian Army set up a 1,000-bed hospital in Rajasthan during the coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: Upon investigation, we found out that all the images were old and two of them were not even from India. One is from the US and another is from Germany. Even the Indian Army clarified on Twitter that such claims are baseless.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Images of the medical facility shared with the claim that the Indian Army set up a 1,000-bed hospital in Rajasthan during the coronavirus pandemic.

Explanation:Upon investigation, we found out that all the images were old and two of them were not even from India. One is from the US and another is from Germany. Even the Indian Army clarified on Twitter that such claims are baseless.

https://marathi.factcrescendo.com/no-indian-army-did-build-1000-bed-hospital-in-two-days-for-in-rajasthan/

Claim: Multiple Facebook and Twitter posts shared thousands of times by Australian social media users claim people with pre-existing respiratory conditions will be given a “rescue pack” of medication from their general practitioners during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Explaination: The claim is false; Australia’s Department of Health dismissed the rumour as “misinformation”, adding that patients will not receive “rescue packs” from their doctors unless previously prescribed.
Label: False

Claim: A photo of a young boy has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and various websites alongside a claim that it shows a 13-year-old who died after contracting the novel coronavirus in the UK in 2020.
Explaination: The claim is false; the photograph has circulated in reports since 2017 about a teenager who died in Ireland.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A photo of a young boy has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and various websites alongside a claim that it shows a 13-year-old who died after contracting the novel coronavirus in the UK in 2020.

Explanation:The claim is false; the photograph has circulated in reports since 2017 about a teenager who died in Ireland.

https://factcheck.afp.com/photo-has-circulated-reports-about-irish-teenager-who-died-2017

Claim: Flu vaccine increases coronavirus risk 36%, says military study.
Explaination: More research is needed to provide a conclusive answer to the question of whether the flu shot increases the risk of non-influenza viral respiratory infections. It is important to keep in mind that while the flu vaccine cannot prevent COVID-19, it still provides several indirect benefits. For example, it reduces cases of flu and flu complications that require hospitalization, in turn reducing the burden on the healthcare system, which has become strained during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Label: No evidence
html:
Claim: Flu vaccine increases coronavirus risk 36%, says military study.

Explanation:More research is needed to provide a conclusive answer to the question of whether the flu shot increases the risk of non-influenza viral respiratory infections. It is important to keep in mind that while the flu vaccine cannot prevent COVID-19, it still provides several indirect benefits. For example, it reduces cases of flu and flu complications that require hospitalization, in turn reducing the burden on the healthcare system, which has become strained during the COVID-19 pandemic.

https://healthfeedback.org/claimreview/claim-that-flu-vaccine-increases-coronavirus-infection-is-unsupported-misinterprets-scientific-studies/

Claim: Four people have died in Zanzibar after handling a chicken infected with COVID-19.
Explaination: A post claiming that four individuals in Zanzibar died from COVID-19 after handling a diseased chicken is false. The post contains images of a diseased chicken that circulated in other countries claiming to show symptoms of COVID-19.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Four people have died in Zanzibar after handling a chicken infected with COVID-19.

Claim: A purported advisory has been shared repeatedly in multiple Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp posts that claims a disinfectant will be sprayed into the air overnight in India in an effort to kill the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The posts urge residents to remain indoors during the spraying.
Explaination: The claim is false; Indian authorities said the advisory was "fake" and that no such measure had been announced.
Label: FALSE
html:
Claim: A purported advisory has been shared repeatedly in multiple Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp posts that claims a disinfectant will be sprayed into the air overnight in India in an effort to kill the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The posts urge residents to remain indoors during the spraying.

Claim: Event 201 “gave out stuffed souvenir coronavirus toys” to “commemorate” novel coronavirus outbreak.
Explaination: Event 201 used a fictionalized coronavirus outbreak as its pandemic scenario but did not "predict" the outbreak of a strain that would be detected two months later in December 2019 in Wuhan, China.
Label: Mostly false
html:

Explanation:The cattle vaccine has nothing to do with the COVID-19 virus.

https://www.factcheck.org/2020/03/cattle-vaccine-not-related-to-2019-novel-coronavirus/

Claim: China officially said the new coronavirus had “confirmed aerosol infection” and that “in short, airborne infections” were spread.
Explaination: Aerosol infections are rare and different from airborne infections.
Label: False
html:
Claim: China officially said the new coronavirus had “confirmed aerosol infection” and that “in short, airborne infections” were spread.

Explanation:Aerosol infections are rare and different from airborne infections.

https://www.buzzfeed.com/jp/kotahatachi/unknown-cause-china-10

Claim: Coronavirus found in toilet paper.
Explaination: This was created by a prank generator, and the CDC did not include this as a way in which coronavirus spreads.
Label: False

annotations.label: CommSpread
annotations.remark: note that it's obvious (presumably) that this was intended as satire

html:
Claim: Coronavirus found in toilet paper.

Explanation:This was created by a prank generator, and the CDC did not include this as a way in which coronavirus spreads.

https://hoax-alert.leadstories.com/3471884-fact-check-covid-19-not-found-in-toilet-paper.html

Claim: North Carolina “hospital beds are typically 85% full across the state.”
Explaination: Records show that NC hospitals are, on average throughout the year, between 60-to-75% full. However, medical professionals say Jackson is right that hospitals operate at maximum capacity during certain parts of the year, such as flu season.
Label: Half True
html:
Claim: North Carolina “hospital beds are typically 85% full across the state.”

Explanation:Records show that NC hospitals are, on average throughout the year, between 60-to-75% full. However, medical professionals say Jackson is right that hospitals operate at maximum capacity during certain parts of the year, such as flu season.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/apr/01/jeff-jackson/are-nc-hospital-beds-typically-85-full/

Claim: Whether microwaving face masks sanitizes them.
Explaination: Research shows that hydrogen peroxide will kill the virus on masks, but no proof has been found that microwaving kills the novel coronavirus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Whether microwaving face masks sanitizes them.

Explanation:Research shows that hydrogen peroxide will kill the virus on masks, but no proof has been found that microwaving kills the novel coronavirus.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/04/Fact-Check-Microwaving-Masks-In-Plastic-Bags-Is-NOT-Safe-Way-To-Sterilize-Them.html

Claim: Myanmar’s former military junta donated Ks 1000 Lakhs to COVID-19 fund.
Explaination: The list of donors in The Mirror daily circulated on March 26 shows no name of former military junta or current army chief or former president.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Myanmar’s former military junta donated Ks 1000 Lakhs to COVID-19 fund.

Explanation:The list of donors in The Mirror daily circulated on March 26 shows no name of former military junta or current army chief or former president.

https://myanmar.factcrescendo.com/fact-check-post-claiming-myanmar-former-military-junta-donates-covid-19-fund/

Claim: Demonstrations against Chinese people in Italy.
Explaination: Anti-fascist demonstration on February 22 in Roma.
Label: FALSE
html:
Claim: Demonstrations against Chinese people in Italy.

Explanation:Anti-fascist demonstration on February 22 in Roma.

https://observers.france24.com/fr/20200311-coronavirus-manifestations-scenes-panique-intox-venues-europe

Claim: Says video shows “the Chinese are destroying the 5G poles as they are aware that it is the thing triggering the corona symptoms.”
Explaination: The video shows Hong Kong protesters tearing down “smart” lampposts because they feared they could be used to collect personal data from citizens.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Says video shows “the Chinese are destroying the 5G poles as they are aware that it is the thing triggering the corona symptoms.”

Explanation:The video shows Hong Kong protesters tearing down “smart” lampposts because they feared they could be used to collect personal data from citizens.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/apr/07/viral-image/no-video-doesnt-show-people-china-destroying-5g-po/
